entry.title: Whether to show images in the Lightbox when clicked
entry.content: true
Had a good time at the ball game tonight. (Btw, note the use of the metasyntactic variable in that address.) We had a great vantage point, but next time I think we're sitting on the lawn, for fun.
Sam showed me a great book full of tips for using the Java programming language™ better.
I'll be reading a bunch of articles on software design by Martin Fowler in the next few days.

Just read (link is flaky today, try Google's cache) about a weblog tool caller Roller built by a local guy with all open source tools. Among the tools used, the most interesting to me was the XDoclet code generator: add a few javadoc tags to your class, and bang, you've got all the extra code you'd need to get database persistence.

He also uses Struts and Velocity for handling page templates. Lately I've been interested in Zope Page Templates. Basically, valid XHTML dummy pages that have their real content filled in by what's essentially an XSL transformation. So no funky code at all in your page templates, and you don't have to have any of your other code working to see how a page might look. While I won't be using Zope any time soon, I'm eager to try templating this way next time I develop a web application. Very nice.
Wireless connection at TriLUG tonight. Nice.

Good practitioner meeting at Cisco: I'm finding myself motivated to really bring ant, cvs, and junit into my workflow. Also interesting is that other revision control systems can handle renaming files & changing directory structures -- a feature I've wanted in cvs.
I'm proud of my lunch: honey-nut cream cheese, raisins, american cheese and fresh spinach on whole wheat. Wash it down with a little sweet tea. Aw yeah.

From that article, a nugget I can remember:

When you are developing in this style you will often have a thought and turn immediately to writing a test, rather than going straight to the code.

Good day. To keep learning Java, I'm writing a Farkle game. Trying to do this test-first with JUnit.

What's even cooler is that, having dug out my classical music CDs from back in 6th grade, I'm sitting at my desk listening to Gershwin and drinking ice water and remembering Grandot.
SOAP interface to Google (via Scripting News). Awesome. Awesome, awesome, awesome.
The new car's license tag ends in 4011. I knew I'd seen that number before, and I just realized it's the produce code on bananas in the supermarket. Goofy.

Becky's going to the Psychology Ph.D. program at the University of Memphis! She writes:

GUESS WHO'S GOING TO LIVE IN THE STATE OF TENNESSEE FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS???? GRACELAND TICKETS ANYONE???????????

Woohoo!

Very sweet dhtml web-based email client: oddpost. Just for IE5+, though you oughtta be able to do all that with standard use of the DOM. Arguably, they were doing all their development work way before Mozilla was close to ready, so there was no real need to be cross-browser compatible. I hope they can convert easily.
On the docket: understand this architecture for web applications, then compare with struts.
Welpers (that's what Brenton would say), I bought the car today! Happy birthday! You know, I'd never wanted to just go driving until I drove this car. Who needs a destination? So much fun to drive!
Oddly, the introduction of the blockquote in the post below caused IE to throw in a horizontal scrollbar with just 1px of wiggle room. I'd thought my stylesheet was kosher. Hmm...

I hope to go canoeing on the Deep River Saturday:

Join us for a day-long canoe trip on the Deep River, which forms the border between Chatham and Lee Counties, North Carolina. The river now drains areas that were mined for iron, coal and gold during years surrounding the War Between the States, and provides historic as well as natural interest. Because the Deep River is a relatively safe waterway, even paddlers with little experience will find the trip enjoyable and rewarding.

I just sent out an email feeler to see if anyone'd like to join me. I hope so. :-)

Working on getting Movable Type going in the new b2g test space. So far it's nothing but Internal Server Errors. Dang. Error logs report Premature end of script headers, which is usually a permissions problem thing. Though I've already chmod'ed the files in the cgi-bin directory properly... hmm...

I'm thinking seriously now about buying Ara's car! I've gotten a lot of good advice for going about the process (esp. keeping the transaction & our friendship orthogonal). I'm gonna get my car worked on next week so it'll be ready to sell. This is so much fun. :-)

I downloaded Together Control Center 6.0 today. I'm waiting (patiently, kinda) for a license key so I can actually try it. Getting into it & seeing their ideas for software development should be really interesting; hard to wait.

Movable Type is running dog slow (depends on the dog) on the ol' 486. Will relocate to either [1] test space with b2g's web host or [2] newer box in the duplex, when repaired & configured. Now, back to the job search... :-)

Had a great patterns group meeting at Barnes & Noble today. Great group of guys, and well-focused intelligent conversation. I think we all had a lot of fun. :) Ideas I'd like to remember/emphasize:

  1. Names are important. The guys in the pragmatic programmer book say they spend a long time -- even half an hour -- thinking of a good name for a particular class or object. It's all writing. Gotta communicate well.

  2. Reuse base class functionality. This is much like Don't Repeat Yourself. Get as much of the shared functionality as high in the inheritance hierarchy as you can, so you won't have to write it over & over again. Extend rather than replace, as in

    void MonoGlyph::Draw (Window* w) {
        _component->Draw(w);
    }

    void Border::Draw (Window* w) {
        MonoGlyph::Draw(w);
        DrawBorder(w);
    }

  3. Favor object composition over inheritance. There's so much more flexibilty this way, and you avoid the explosion of classes that can come from an inheritance-based approach -- BorderedComposition, ScrollableComposition, BorderedScrollableComposition...

  4. The biggest abstract factory gain happens at creation time. It's not enough to have parallel families of widgets unless you can specify in just one place which particular family you want to use. Specifying which concrete factory to use is that one place.

Also good for me to remember is that the class diagram notation is documented inside the back cover. :)
Movable Type looks like a good solution for the b2g site. Trying it out will require busting out my mad perl skillz. ;-)
Brenton and I are in the Bryan Center thinking about how to support on the b2g website the kind of interaction that would best serve the community. Interesting ideas are floating around here...
Huh, my Palm email & schedule conduits have vanished. I guess we all need a little mystery in our lives.
Gosh, my email's flaky today. Time to get some work done.
Seven years of software design newsletters at thecoadletter.com. Now reading one about database table <-> object relationships. Nice.

It's a waste of time, but as I'm re-organizing my paper files, I'm noting various statistics in my Duke eating habits as recorded on the DukeCard statements. First meal from a merchant on points: 9/7/96 -- Subway, $6.25. Total meals at Han's Chinese Cuisine: 94 (Is that all?). I was going to throw these away, but it's all so interesting now...
Dude, I just downloaded blogBuddy, a windows tool that lets you publish to a weblog via the Blogger API. This is sooo much faster than going through Blogger's web interface. Great!

Map URLs in Email

It is not easy to type a link to a Yahoo! or MapQuest map.

Yahoo! Maps gives you a [1] long and [2] ugly URL for its search result, so you have to do the actual search yourself and then cut & paste: http://maps.yahoo.com/py/maps.py?addr=902+Dacian+Ave&csz=27701. There's no way you could (or would want to be able to) construct a link like this from memory.

Google provided a better alternative (with an intermediate click) when they started recognizing US street addresses: a few times now I've directly typed a link like this to send people: http://www.google.com/search?q=902+Dacian+27701.

I have a suggestion. Here's the sort of address (except for the odd hostname) I could remember and type in an email: http://todd.durham.nc.us/map/902DacianAve/27701.

TriJUG .NET Talk

Last night: went to Sam Ruby's TriJUG talk on .NET. I took some notes afterwards that I'll add here later. For now, here's his reaction.
For fun, reading up on Ruby, an object-oriented scripting language recommended for quick-and-dirty prototyping. Interesting...

On reading up for Friday's php dav server idea, I realized php operates too high to handle the raw http request. Dang. A relevant thread on a w3c mailing list.

Maybe we do it this way: xml-rpc based file uploading. Write a simple windows gui in vb or something that Gary could use. Again, the point of all this is to be able to attach event handlers to changes in the site content.
Wow! My illustrious running career is out for all to see. (As are Mom and Dad's.) Those aren't our real pictures. :)
Just went looking on eBay for a deer head to put over the fireplace. Got just a little bit freaked out. Maybe I won't do this after all. Ick...
BTW, U2's post-9/11 performance of Walk On with the Peace on Earth lead-in and the Hallelujah, I'll see you when I get home trailer was just playing on the radio. Sweet.

Some thoughts on getting stuff online: I've done a couple of things, first direct sql statements (very bad), then ftp'ing xml documents. Mind bomb: a php webdav frontend to whatever storage system I use, complete with hooks for doing things like invalidating cached layout when a document is updated. The end goal is to manage the whole website with a nice gui filesystem-looking thing. Save a word document as (x)html, and drop it over. Make a new directory. Yowza.

All that translation stuff below is a testing project so I can begin to conceptualize how xslt would fit into a good publishing system. Principles (from the Pragmatic Programmer book) I'd like to stick to include:

  1. Don't Repeat Yourself. Must the xml format and the xsl stylesheet be so tightly coupled?

  2. Keep Knowledge in Plain Text. Is it possible to specify the actual transformation in a simple text file that the xsl can read in and understand?

  3. Write Code That Writes Code. To keep from repeating myself, can I write a little perl script to generate [1] the database schema, [2] the xml dtd for a particular document and [3] the stylesheet for displaying said xml all from the same plain text file?

I could go on...
Today I have translated into xhtml the opml version of Scripting News via XSLT (an xml-based language for transforming one xml tree into another) with PHP. How's them for acronyms.
Quiet for a while. Still looking for work, reading two great books, and enjoying the new duplex.

Biggest takeaway for me from last night was No Broken Windows. Two examples:

  • Sociologists parked a Mercedes in a rough part of the Bronx, then hid to observe. Four days, nothing happened to it. They then broke out a small vent window in the back, retreated, and within 40 minutes the whole car had been gutted, flipped over, and set on fire.

  • One broken apartment window left unfixed: people step over the glass on the sidewalk, no one cleans it up, and when another window gets broken, no one cares. It snowballs, and the whole neighborhood goes down, not just the one building.

As you cut corners here & there (short cuts make for long delays) and leave bad code half done, you demotivate your teammates and yourself. This will cut productivity so much that you'll lose far more time than you saved with the ugly hack in the first place.

More notes on the TriJUG talk: It was great. People-focused software development methodologies. Conway's (?) Law: The structure of your code reflects the organization of your development team. Fascinating. Some ideas summarized at agilealliance.org.
Check out this mind game referenced in the book written by the speaker at last night's TriJUG meeting.
Working on the ol' resume this morning and finding that the websites I usually check in the morning are a HUGE distraction. Maybe it's time to delete some bookmarks.
"It looks simple, but when you try to make it in chocolate, it's more complicated." --Jacques Torres, host of FoodTV's Chocolate, on building the Eiffel tower.

Back to Windows on the laptop so I can make progress on Ara's code. The really cool benefit here is that I can now do email on my palm pilot. This is great for getting driving directions where I can use them in the car.
Just about got that letter finished. Yahoo!
Had a great lunch today with my friend Ryan and his friend Drew from work. Mostly talked shop, and they pointed me to a place around here where I might try applying. We'll see...
Afternoon goal: write a letter/thank you note about the last year and a half working with b2g. It's been waaay too long.
Google is making a drop-in appliance to index the documents on a corporate intranet. It's yellow. Nice.
Wrote Phase I of an RIS whitepaper this morning.

Fascinating assessment of .NET: Playing with the .NET SDK, the cross-language support looks impressive, but the illusion holds true only until realizing that all languages in the mix are virtually identical. Microsoft has actually invented the concept of skinnable language: changing a language’s most superficial aspects, and claiming the result to be a new language.
Dude, this guy's awesome. Homemade antennas got him into a distant wireless network at 2Mb/s.

Odd. I woke up this morning to an automated phone call selling life insurance to people 50 and over. I hung up but it called me back, every minute on the minute. Eventually I turned my phone off, and the thing kept going for an hour until it filled up my voicemail box.

It wasn't malicious or anything, but it sure felt like it. Those guys got a bum deal on their phone spam software, that's for sure.
It's high time to establish a solid Liverpool Rummy influence in the 919 area code. (I'd post a link to the rules, but nowhere I've seen online gets them "right.")
Going to talk with Sam's friend Regan tonight about maybe lending a hand on his company's website.
Made an appointment with Duke's Career Center to get some job search help next Friday. Replied to a TriJUG job posting or two, and getting ready to get in touch with Bix's company, just in case.

Looking again at the code for Ara, we've hit a snag. The code we're porting makes fairly heavy use of the Intel Signal Processing Library, designed to run only in Windows on x86 hardware. Grrr. Looking for replacements...
It's Groundhog Day!
Hey, I'll be heading to Knoxville tomorrow! A quick trip home to get my eyes checked, talk about a project with Dad & Mike, and eat some good home-cookin'. (Thanks, Mom.)

#include "transducer.h"
#include "impulse.h"
#include "transmit.h"
#include "receiver.h"
#include "signal.h"

I've just taken a look at some simulation code Ara wants to port from Windows to Linux. Looks like it's well-designed enough that the whole process will be quite simple. This is a Good Thing™.
This morning: grokking struts.
I've borrowed Sam's copy of the Gang of Four book, and I'm getting into it like I wish I had in CPS 108 at Duke. Fun stuff.

DBR's positive spin on it: In the long run, it will probably be a very useful loss, and our guess is that in the very near future, leaders will be flushed out, a hardening attitude will creep into Duke's play, and things will improve sharply and quite quickly. We're very fortunate to have a great teacher on our side, and there is a great deal to be learned from this game.

It's still a little hard to deal with, though.
Hoping to get some work done on something -- anything -- tomorrow. Possible projects include Java on Linux, ppp bridging the laptop's internet connection to the Palm, and cleaning my room.
Well, the snow's stopped. Call it 10 inches total.

Well, it did snow. There's about half a foot on the ground now, and we'll probably get about that much more this afternoon.

The local NBC affiliate has snow pictures people've sent in from around the area.
It looks like we may get some snow over here this evening! I suppose I'd better get home soon...
I've read the first two Harry Potter books these past few days. Really fun reading. Hoping to get back into The Hobbit next.
Free WiFi in the Regulator Bookshop basement. Sweet. I'd love to hear of more places around RDU that do this.
Happy New Year! (A little late.)
DBR: Not long after [the 5 starters returned to the game], Jason Williams went into the phone booth and put on his cape.

I didn't see yesterday's game, but DBR had good things to say:

On Matt Christensen: When K challenged the team's energy in an earlier game, Christensen bellowed, "I've got energy!" and then went out and proved it. In Sunday's game, he performed a similar role. There was no pushing him around, and he gave better than he got. Let's face it: Matt has limited mobility, which is not helped by his knees, and consequently doesn't shoot well. But what he can do better than anyone else on this team is to bang, and bang he did. He pretty much put an end to the most extremely physical defense, all by himself.

On Casey Sanders: Someone else who probably made an impression on A&T was Casey Sanders, who had a lot of fun blocking shots. You see it more and more in recent games: someone drives, goes up - and there is this long arm two feet over them. There's just not much you can do, and Casey's swats are starting to affect games.
Gosh, these guys are smart.

Sweet. I've been banging my head against what appears to be an IE bug all day long, and I've just found the solution. I wanted an <input type="text" /> to stretch to the width of its containing element, so I added the appropriate width:100%; line to the stylesheet. This worked in Mozilla, but IE barfed and gave me a text input field the width of the whole screen! SOLUTION: I needed to explicitly supply the containing element's width in the stylesheet as well. (I had just been doing absolute positioning giving both a left and right side.) The fixed layout will show up on the b2g contacts page sometime next week!

Sir Nathan of Abele: We, the denizens of Abele of Crowelle, have stumbled upon a fantastical mysterie. The forebeares of our dwelling place had the forethought to bestowe a legacie of gracious boone on our behalf. Just this even-tide, we had the great fortune to unearthe manifold treasure in the tiled roofe above our verie heades.

I've been scoping out portable mp3 players. Nothing out there seems great, except for the iPod, which doesn't really work with anything non-Macintosh. The ideal player would hold around 1GB and transfer files over ethernet. Maybe it would come with an ethernet-connected recharging cradle.

It's gettin kinda late, but in an attempt to be helpful I've put together a Christmas list at Amazon. Also at Eddie Bauer, but I haven't found a way to link to that one yet. Some other things I couldn't find at Amazon include a PCI TV card.
Most interesting from last night's embedded Linux talk: busybox. PHENOMENAL COSMIC POWERS --- cat, grep, find, tar --- itty-bitty living space.
Happy birthday, Grandmommy!

Funny: Since roughly 11:30 Saturday evening, college football has been scrambling about in absolute chaos. No one can agree on who should play Miami for that sport's alleged national championship. Oregon? Colorado? Nebraska? Perhaps we could throw a set of shoulder pads on Carlos Boozer and Jason Williams and have the Hurricanes play Duke.

Also funny: I dreamed I saw the northern lights last night, and they suffered from JPEG compression artifacts.
I'm off to an NC*SA talk on embedded Linux. Should be pretty cool!
Well, it looks like the CD-ROM may not work: PHP would require a .dll file copied to the windows/system directory. Bummer.
Happy birthday, Becky!

This afternoon's project: get a CD-ROM with Apache, PHP, MySQL and a copy of the b2g website for offline demos of what we've got so far. Ideally, this would work on lots of platforms and require nothing but a double-click to get going. Well, we'll see...
I figured I must have been feeling German when I ordered a reuben with potato salad for lunch. Dude, I'm full now.
New layout. I'm digging it. :)
Search Google for Os Guinness The Call, and the b2g site comes up first! Nice.

I've been spending the morning upgrading the b2g development server to Debian's testing release since it has a package for handling Windows' web folders. It's taken the whole morning because the box is a 486 with 40M of ram. :)
There seems to be a lot of buzz online about the Segway scooter thing. Looks cool to me!

Hi. Today's been fun.

I've been thinking about writing my own weblog code to avoid two problems I've had with Blogger: slow server response time (keeping me from wanting to write more often) and plaintext-password ftp publishing (making me quite paranoid security-wise).

Along the way, this has become a way to practice using Perl and to think about object-oriented design. I'm also getting a lesson in reusing components: for example, the Apache project has an XSLT engine that would shoulder much of the weight of publishing in multiple formats for me.

The interesting part of the project now is figuring out how to handle new content: What data format to use? What sort of editor?

At any rate, I feel good right now. It's been a restful day.
I will no longer have to type in email addresses. Evolution, my email client, now syncs well with my Palm. Sweet.
Not much to say, just didn't want to leave a bad Duke link up top on the page. We're playing much better now, thanks.
DBR was not happy with last night's game. But I'm looking forward to seeing the character this team takes on -- it's obviously still forming, but it won't be what last year's was. And that's good.

I got back into Perl today after taking the weekend off. I don't want to quit for the day yet; just feels like there's not enough time to get it all in. I downloaded some modules to do XML-RPC and actually understood most of their code! I thought I'd run a server inside Apache, but what I've seen so far is standalone... interesting.

Looking forward to Duke v. Seton Hall tonight, and going to have folks over for tomorrow night's game + soup!
It's awesome, baby!
The Perl learning is going... very... slooooooowly. But I think I'm about to turn the corner into producing a simple discussion forum as a learning project. Go, baby, go.

Today I made the initial contact with two local companies about working for them. The first looks like a lot of fun; the second looks like a stretch that would be good. I am going out to buy a Perl book or two.

I wrote the following for a cover letter, then realized that mixing metaphors can get silly:

Since graduating from Duke in 2000, I've had a great time getting a startup community site -- b2g.org -- up on its feet. Now I'm looking for some new projects to tackle.
Still working to build the narrative flow of the b2g website. Today's progress: friendly messages like this one when no one's yet registered nearby.

Did you know: individuals can get .us domain names for free!

So I did.

todd.durham.nc.us is this page and matthew@todd.durham.nc.us works for my email. Kinda dorky, but still fun.

I'm (deludedly?) imagining a more grassroots approach to the web where more people are online with names like this. I'm considering dumping the hept.net domain name as well...

From an excellent article passed along by Kristie Monteiro:

Eventually, spending four nights a week at the church might come to be seen as a lack of love and not as the height of spirituality.
Sweet.

b2g.org (almost) live. Old sites: holding patterns. Layout: A-OK. Database: Replicated. Files: No dice. Bogus FTP password was sent the first time, now waiting on a replacement, could be Monday before we get results. In the meantime, I'm going to dinner.
When the database is down or someone types in a bad filename, the new b2g code now does some nice error handling instead of going down in flames. I may like writing code.

The new b2g site is getting oh-so-close to being done. I've decided that I'm going to go wild when it's live and move this site to my own well-designed Java servlet-in Apache Tomcat-XML RPC accessible-custom weblog system. Cause I want to tackle a fun project like that.

This weekend I got pretty frustrated trying to turn an old 486 into a router so David & I could be online at the same time. I probably fried some stuff permanently. *sigh*

Thursday Andrew & I are going to undertake an insane hike from end to end of the Smokies on the Appalachian Trail. Should be pretty doable if we pack light, except for Sunday: 23 miles. Oof.

John Elderedge:

The history of a man's relationship with God is the story of how God calls him out, takes him on a journey and gives him his true name. Most of us have thought it was the story of how God sits on his throne waiting to whack a man broadside when he steps out of line. Not so.

From Pat Conroy:

I realized that I had satisfied myself with observer status in the human race for too long. Caution had wounded me. Fear had gotten too tight a hold on me; it had slowed my step, eclipsed my spontaneity, my willingness to take a corner on two wheels. I saw myself as I was, framed in that window -- a man afraid of women, of love, of passions, and the staying power of friends. At this crossroads of my life, all ways looked appealing and I knew that was exactly what was wrong with me.

It's been a while. Today's entry is threefold:

  1. I'm using a wireless network card in the Bryan Center. This is quite nice.
  2. Read Psalm 107 this morning.
  3. This song is on the radio, and I like it:

    It's been a while
    Since I could...
    Hold my head up high

    And it's been a while
    Since I said I'm sorry.
With caffeine'd veins and bloodshot eyes, I, trembling, slew the dragon. In other words, b2g people search is on the brink of reality. I'm also learning to tu tyo ty[ typr type, type.

I'm in Colorado right now for a Navigators web conference, currently sitting in a visiting scholars cubicle with a T1 internet connection.

Last night Tristan, Kanae & I went to Bavariafest over in Raleigh where we sat at an outdoor picnic table with our bratwurst, sauerkraut and German beer. Quite nice, except for the polka band. :)

So I think the 486 got cracked the other day, probably as a result of my ldap server install, but I'm not really sure. Anyway, I just put OpenBSD on it in place of the Debian Linux distribution. OpenBSD is supposed to be more secure out of the box, so much so that their logo looks like this:

Cool.

Today has been an awesome php day. I have successfully written modules to:

  • Parse custom xml documents.
  • Glean id3v1 info from mp3 files.
  • Read jpeg comments.

These are all Good Things because self-describing data makes b2g website publishing a simple matter of ftp'ing files -- no more separate databases with file attributes, and no more messy web forms. Yeah!
<alert type="geekism">I can login to the laptop from my palm.</alert>

More from Brennan Manning:

While the imposter draws his identity from past achievements and the adulation of others, the true self claims identity in its belovedness. We encounter God in the ordinariness of life: not in the search for spiritual highs and extraordinary, mystical experiences but in our simple presence in life.

I would like to live this way.

Mark & I drove 55 yesterday to see if it would help his gas mileage. Some memorable moments: Everybody's passing us. I think I'm becoming a road hazard. *Yawn* Are we there yet? The verdict: 3mpg better, probably Not Worth It.

Later we drove all over NE Durham county looking or a good place to see last night's supposed meteor shower. Ended up facing east just above the waterline on a Falls Lake boat ramp.

Hi. Yesterday I went to play basketball on central campus. I'm learning that basketball is all about cojones. You hang back, stay out of things, try to play it safe, and you're a loser. Practicing foul shots is nothing compared to playing the game.

So I had one victory yesterday: the guy guarding me stole the ball and took off down the court. I usually collapse when that happens, but this time I ran after him, caught up with him, and got me and my arm up in the air between him and the basket, no foul, to try to block his layup. I didn't touch the ball and I came down on his foot, and I still don't know if the shot went in or not.

Everyone on his team congratulated him, then one guy said to me, Good D. Courage, risk. Cojones.

Brennan Manning:

The decision to come out of hiding is our own initiation rite into the healing ministry of Jesus Christ.

Today is b2g website research day. I feel that it's time for a new solution. Some alternatives:

  • PHP + MySQL at Gospelcom (current setup)
  • Custom ColdFusion solution with the Navigators
  • An ASP model, like FusionPage
  • Some pre-fabbed publishing software, like Zope

I've mentioned Duke and basketball more than I would have expected here. We've had good games with Monmouth, Mizzou, UCLA and USC, and now it's the final four. To quote Shane Battier:

It?s the best time of the year, and this has been my goal all year long ? to get back to the Final Four. And now that we?re at the dance, it?s time to boogie.
I was there when Duke won three more times. It was awesome, baby.
Duke beat Carolina yesterday. And it was good.

Daily update: Tristan & I listened to Car Talk, looked at rental houses for him & Kanae, and ate lunch at Burger King. This afternoon I moved the 486 into the closet; you wouldn't believe how much quieter the living room is now. Mark Lim came over for dinner; dinner was good. I did some web research and got us an ACC Tournament place to stay near a bus route to the train station. Cheap, too. :) Finally, it's hard to see it below, but I'm trying weird facial hair.
Tristan just won 2 ACC Tournament tickets!!! And I get to go!!! (Turns out we'll be in the Carolina section, so incognito's the word... kinda.) Should be a lot of fun. Go Duke!

This past weekend I went to an awesome conference in Colorado Springs. Here's a picture of a bunch of Duke folks (Jami, Gary, Julia, Dean, Me, Dave, Sam, Shannon, Lorie, Bethany) there:

I met so many people and had so many great conversations that now I feel like I'm in a sensory deprivation chamber. Kind of hard to adjust back, I guess. But man, what a weekend.
Congratulations, it's a website. 7lbs, 4oz. I think it has my chin.
Sitting in awe. Just faxed a tax form from the laptop. Yeah, baby.
When you sit in a wooden cafe chair for 8 hours a day, day after day, you get sore. My grandmother calls it TB, for <q>tired bottom.</q> Amen to that.

Dad describes the Great Squirrel Eradication beautifully:

The squirrel stood motionless for what seemed like an eternity. His ears pricked up at the rustle of leaves on the deck below. The warm afternoon sun bore down on his stupid little eyes as he strained to see if anyone was near. With one final check, he turned and sneaked into the metal contraption, intent on taking the PBB [ed. note: peanut butter bait], and then... SLAM, sucker. You're number four!!!

About 3 weeks into this web log thing, I'm becoming aware of posting the same stuff day after day: Well, I'm back in the cafe at Duke again... The website's doing well... Here's hoping we up the personal level a twidget.
Good day. Early Breakfast with Ed, then working in the apartment on the contact form. Cooking chicken for dinner...
I mentioned Car Talk the other day. Tristan & I have almost made it a weekend ritual. I like the Weekly Puzzlers: listen to this one in RealAudio format.

Back in the cafe. Brought the current template into the development version of the web site. I need to get some exercise...

Mark Lim and I went a little crazy last night and bought another domain name. How cool is this: matthew@myemailaddressislongerthanyours.com.

Yesterday I had lunch with Aunt Kitty in High Point and watched Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon with a bunch of friends at the Carolina Theatre. Both were quite cool.

Today is a good day for Prarie Home Companion and Car Talk. Kinda nice just listening to the radio sometimes.
Call me sappy, but I like this song pretty well. (Listen to it in RealAudio format.)

Calvinball rules, from a post on Slashdot. So that's 2 sports mentioned in the same day...

In other news, today has seen some fantastic progress on my b2g work. I will have the whole user profile section done tonight!
Last night's game. *Sigh*
I'm over at Duke today. Sitting in the cafe with the laptop, listening to music, seeing friends walk by. Aw yeah. Back to work.

Quote for the day from a book I'm reading:

It's never a sin to ask for love; it's always a sin to try to earn it.

Working today on a (begin meaningless technical term) user information database abstraction layer (end meaningless technical term) that will make it easier to handle b2g registration, user profiles, and address books. Just finished all the functions that will let me read from the database; next up: writing to the database (woo hoo).

Also, my favorite thing about the switch back to Windows: the Google toolbar.
Well, I've been playing all day with the laptop: Windows is working. Made the switch to try out the new webcam. Pretty cool.
Just watched Casablanca with Robert, David & Jen. Not bad; not bad at all. Here's looking at you, kid.

Today has seen some good progress. I've finished writing a letter home and almost fleshed out the interface design for one of my key PHP classes. Tonight I will go to the grocery store, address some envelopes, and maybe reinstall windows on the laptop.

Wow, Psalm 4:

Many are asking, Who can show us any good?
Let the light of your face shine upon us, O LORD.
A bunch of us are getting together at Kanae's place to watch a cubicle dweller's movie. I hear it's pretty funny. Did you know you can order pizza online? How cool is that?
I've gotten to do some web research today on securing trademark and copyright coverage for b2g and Ed's Next Step & Graduate's Corner work. Interesting.
God remembered and sent.

I'm seeing strange things happening with my PHP code today. All sorts of "Document contained no data" stuff down in the bowels of the site. Seemingly voodoo, probably my doing. Update: yes, it was. One missing semicolon, error messages suppressed. Yeehaw.
Three goals that make sense now just as they did 4 years ago.

Mark Lim & I spent last night watching James, David & Elena. I'm pretty tired. Also, I downloaded a Bible reading plan onto my Palm. I'm having to change all the dates one by one; it might have been easier if I were running Windows. Oh well.

Now playing: U2's new one. In a Little While is one of my favorites:

In a little while,
Surely you'll be mine.
In a little while I'll be there.
In a little while,
This hurt will hurt no more.
I'll be home, love.

Tristan and I are going to Chili's for dinner. He's in the middle of some pretty exciting job interviews with tech companies over here. Darren is driving down from D.C. tonight and will be staying at our apartment. I'm looking forward to catching up with him.
I think it's all like I like it now. :) I'm pretty excited about using this page to chronicle the day-to-day stuff. Maybe this will make it easier to keep in touch back home.
I am experimenting with this new "blog" service at blogger.com. So far it's pretty nice.
